questions.text: Identify the amputation done at the level shown in the below radiograph.
questions.solution:
Chopart amputation is done at the level shown in the above radiograph.

Chopart amputation is a type of midfoot amputation through the talonavicular joint and calcaneocuboid joint. One of the indications is diabetic foot. It can be done only if calcaneum and talus are free of infection.

The image below shows X-ray foot after Chopart's amputation.

Other options:

Option A: Pirogoff amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation. It involves a vertical section through the middle of the calcaneum followed by arthrodesis between the tibia and the remaining part of the calcaneum.

Option B: Syme's amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation where the bone section is done at the distal tibia and fibula.

Option C: Lisfranc amputation is a type of midfoot amputation that is done at the level of tarsometatarsal joints.

questions.text: A plain radiograph of a patient who was involved in a road traffic accident is as given below. During clinical examination his limb would be found to be:
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph of this patient shows anterior dislocation of the hip. On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. 

Other findings in anterior dislocation of the hip joint include a slightly flexed limb and a prominent anterior bulge in the pubic or groin region. According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as -

  • Type I - If the femoral head is felt anteriorly it is called as the superior/pubic type
  • Type II - If the femoral head is felt in the groin it is called as the inferior/obturator type

On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side. A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

The most common nerve injured in an anterior hip dislocation is the femoral nerve.

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The image below shows, a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Posterior dislocation of the hip is more common than anterior dislocation. It is caused due to a high energy impact to the knee, forcing the femoral head posteriorly.

On examination, the limb is adducted and internally rotated in a posterior dislocation of the hip. It also tends to be shortened and slightly flexed. On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head is higher and appears smaller than the normal side.

The most common nerve injured is the sciatic nerve as it lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum.

Treatment of posterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presented with mild pain and swelling of his arm. His plain radiograph revealed a well-defined lytic lesion in the metaphysis and a fallen fragment sign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a 13-year old boy with mild pain and swelling and mentioned radiograph findings point to a diagnosis of a simple (unicameral) bone cyst with a fracture.

Simple bone cyst presents most commonly in the first two decades of life and is more common in males than females. It is due to a defect in the metaphyseal remodeling which blocks the drainage of interstitial fluid. This leads to increased pressure which leads to focal bone necrosis and accumulation of fluid. 

The most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis. They start as metaphyseal lesions but may abut the growing physis.

On radiology, a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen. The cyst may expand concentrically but never penetrates the cortex. No periosteal reaction is seen unless there is a fracture. A thinned cortical fragment may fracture and fall into the base of the cyst, referred to as the fallen fragment sign. It is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst with a fracture. It is shown in the image below.

Treatment:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities - an observation with serial plain X-rays.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk of pathologic fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities:
    • Curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation)
    • Aspiration
    • Injection with corticosteroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or other materials.
  • Fractures through simple bone cysts in the proximal femur and humerus - curettage, bone grafting, and internal fixation with flexible intramedullary nailing 

Other options:

Option B: Osteoclastoma (GCT) usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in their 20's and 30’s. They are solitary, eccentric in location, and most often sub-chondral. They are epiphyseal lytic lesion with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.on X-ray. Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option C: Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. Most of these lesions are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally.

Option D: Aneurysmal bone cysts are benign, locally destructive, multiloculated cysts filled with blood. They are eccentric, expansile, and lytic lesions. Most occur in patients younger than 20 years old. There is a slight female preponderance. The most common sites involved are the proximal humerus, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with left hip pain and an inability to walk after a slip and fall at home 5 days ago. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. Her X-ray is given below.  Which of the following is appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly female with a history of trivial injury, shortened, externally rotated lower limb, and X-ray showing a transverse break in the neck of the femur is suggestive of a fracture of the neck of the femur. In the above scenario, since the age is less than 60 and the duration of injury less than 3 weeks, the appropriate treatment is an internal screw fixation.

In fracture neck of femur, internal fixation is performed with a minimum of 3 cannulated screws. 

Fracture neck of femur is more often seen in fifth to the sixth decade of life and generally occurs after trivial trauma. Examination of the affected limb will reveal external rotation, shortening of the limb, groin tenderness, pain with movement, and no active straight leg raising. 

Treatment of fracture neck of femur depends on the age of the patient and duration of the injury.

In undisplaced fracture, fixation is performed with multiple screws. In a displaced fracture:

  • For people less than age 60 years of age, internal fixation with multiple screws is performed
  • For people greater than 60 years of age, having a:
    • Hip with pre-existing arthritis, a total hip replacement is done
    • Normal hip, a hemiarthroplasty is performed

McMurray's osteotomy is an old procedure used to fix fractures of the neck of the femur, where an oblique osteotomy was performed at the intertrochanteric area. This converts the forces at the fracture site into compressive forces to enhance union. 

 

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient  presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

Match the following

2) Smith’s fracture B) Fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius
3) Colles’ fracture C) Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
4) Monteggia fracture D) Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C,2-D,3-A,4-B.

  • Galeazzi fracture - Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • Smith's fracture - Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.
  • Colles' fracture - Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment.
  • Monteggia fracture - Fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation:

It is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. It is caused by a fall on the hand usually associated with a superimposed rotation force. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

Smith's fracture:

It is also known as reverse Colles' fracture. It is the fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement. The characteristic deformity seen is the 'garden-spade deformity'. 

Colles' fracture:

It is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. The patient presents with pain, swelling, and dinner fork deformity of the wrist. The 'dinner fork deformity ' is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. 

Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks. Closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast is the treatment of choice for displaced fractures.

Monteggia fracture:

It is the fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It can be an extension or flexion type. In extension type, there is anterior angulation of the ulna fracture and anterior dislocation of the head of the radius. In flexion type, there is posterior angulation of the ulna fracture and posterior dislocation of the head of the radius.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of protein C deficiency presents with a painful limp on the right side. His parents give a history of limping after he comes home after playing, 1 week back. On examination,  he is afebrile. The boy whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and relieves by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The below radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.

Treatment:

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates

Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy

For children aged 9 and above - operative management with pelvic osteotomy

Other options:

Option A- Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option B- Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder.

Option D- Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Trethowan's sign is seen in the x-ray and the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis.

In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by the Hilgenreiner’s line and the Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

questions.text: A patient complained of stiffness and pain in the elbow, which is aggravated when he lifts objects. An arthroscopic release of extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon was done, after failed conservative therapy. Which of the following clinical tests would not have been positive before the surgery?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with stiffness and pain in the elbow, which is aggravated on lifting objects and treated with arthroscopic release of extensor carpi radialis brevis is suggestive of Lateral epicondylitis or Tennis elbow, in which reverse Cozen's test will not elicit pain.

Reverse Cozen sign is positive in golfer's elbow or medial epicondylitis- Resisted wrist and finger flexion in pronation elicit pain and tenderness over the medial epicondyle.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is tendinopathy characterized by pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at the origin during activities that involve repeated forceful wrist extension and supination (Eg: backhand in tennis and use of a screwdriver). 

Patients present with outer elbow pain, radiating down the forearm and along with morning stiffness of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting objects and shaking hands. The elbow may appear normal or have slight swelling, with a full range of movement.

Tenderness is present over the lateral epicondyle. Clinical tests for tennis elbow are:

  • Cozen's test: Resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test: extension of the middle finger against resistance elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mill's sign: Extension of the elbow in pronation with a flexed wrist elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Management:

  • Conservative management (consisting of rest, physiotherapy, and exercises)
  • A counterforce brace: releases the forces in the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) region. The counterforce brace acts by compression of the extensor muscles thereby preventing the tension from transmitting up to the lateral epicondyle. It is shown below.
  • Injection of local anesthetic and steroids
  • Mill’s Maneuver: Forceful extension of a fully flexed and pronated forearm after the injection may be attempted. Rarely performed now.

Surgical methods

  • Arthroscopic or percutaneous release of ERCB and/or epicondylar muscles
  • Bosworth technique: Involves the excision of the proximal portion of the annular ligament, the release of the origin of the extensor muscles, excision of the bursa, and excision of synovial fringes.

Other methods of management: extracorporeal shock wave therapy, autologous blood injections, rehabilitative exercises, and ultrasound-guided percutaneous needle therapy.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional swimmer presents to the OPD with complaints of pain over his right shoulder. He gives a history that the pain is usually present after swimming practice sessions. On examination, the pain is aggravated when the arm is abducted between 60-120 degrees and the Hawkins-Kennedy test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of painful arc syndrome.

Painful arc syndrome also known as impingement syndrome is a clinical syndrome in which there is pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range (between 60-120 degrees) of shoulder abduction. This arises because of the repetitive rubbing of the supraspinatus tendon under the coracoacromial arch.

Causes include:

  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity 
  • Subacromial bursitis.

Important tests for impingement:

  • Painful arc test: When the patient is asked to actively abduct the arm, pain is aggravated during 60-120 degrees of abduction.
  • Neer's impingement sign- The examiner raises the affected arm to the full extent in passive flexion, abduction and internal rotation, with the scapula being stabilized with the other hand. The test is positive when pain located to the subacromial space or anterior edge of the acromion is elicited during the test.
  • Neer’s test for impingement: Disappearance or significant reduction in pain when the previous maneuver is repeated after injecting 10 mL of 1% lignocaine into the subacromial space. It helps in the confirmation of the diagnosis.
  • Hawkin-Kennedy's test- The patient's arm is elevated to 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the elbow flexed to 90 degrees. The examiner internally rotates the arm to full extent after stabilizing the upper arm with the other hand. The test is said to be positive when there is pain in the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder.
  • Jobe's test- The patient's arm is elevated in the scapular plane, and the elbow is extended with the thumb pointing to the floor. The patient is then asked to hold this position, while the examiner applies downward pressure. Pain indicates irritation of the supraspinatus tendon.

Other options:

Option B: Frozen shoulder/Periarthritis shoulder-Frozen shoulder is defined as the disorder characterised by progressive pain and stiffness in the shoulder joint which spontaneously resolves after around 18 months. The patient is usually in the age group of 40-60 years, presenting with pain in the shoulder which is initially worst at night but , later pain is present throughout the day and with all the movements.

 Option C: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Option D: Meralgia paraesthetica- It occurs due to entrapment of lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh in the fascia just medial to anterior superior iliac spine leading to numbness, tingling and burning sensation in the area supplies by the nerve.

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a Colles' fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction?

choices.text: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation
Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.solution:
The correct order of reduction of Colles' fracture is traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP.

Colle's fracture refers to the extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture are:

  • Impaction of fragments
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal displacement
  • Lateral tilt (radial tilt)
  • Lateral displacement (radial displacement)
  • Supination

The patient usually presents with pain, swelling, and deformity of the wrist. There may be a typical 'dinner-fork deformity' where the radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level or a little higher than the ulnar styloid process. A dorsal tilt is characteristic and is seen on a lateral x-ray.

Management of Colles' fracture:

  • Undisplaced fractures: immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks
  • Displaced fractures: closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast. The technique of reduction of Colles' fracture is as follows: 
    • Dis-impaction of the fracture fragments by longitudinal traction against counter traction provided by the assistant. 
    • The distal fragment is then pressed into palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation.
    • The patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.
    • A Colles' cast is then applied, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, with the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. 
    • Surgical correction is advisable for comminuted fractures, especially in young adults where the dominant hand is involved. It can be with percutaneous K-wire fixation, external fixators, or locking compression plates.

Complications:

  • Stiffness of joints - finger stiffness is commonly seen
  • Malunion - can produce dinner-fork deformity
  • Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - uncommon
  • Sudek's osteodystrophy - Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of this condition in the upper limb.
  • Rupture of extensor pollicis longus tendon - extremely rare

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male comes into the ER with pain around his ankle after twisting his ankle while playing football. Which of the following indicates the need for ankle X-rays according to Ottawa rules?

1 - Pain around the malleolus
2 - Numbness distal to the ankle
3 - Inability to bear weight on the ankle
4 - Bone tenderness at the posterior edge of the medial or lateral malleolus 
5 - Ability to take 10 steps in the ER
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of an ankle injury. The Ottawa ankle rules are used to determine the need for ankle X-rays in such cases.

The Ottawa ankle rules state that an x-ray is needed if any of the following conditions are met-

  1. Pain around the malleolar zone. 
  2. Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral/medial malleolus/base of the 5th metatarsal bone. 
  3. An inability to bear weight immediately after the injury.
  4. Inability to walk 4 steps in the emergency department.

Acute injury of lateral ligaments of the ankle:

Clinical features -  Presents with a  history of a twisting injury. Pain and swelling may be present. A sprain is suspected if the patient is able to walk and bruising is only faint and slow to appear; a more severe injury is suspected if bruising is marked and the patient is unable to put any weight on the foot.

Investigation - X-ray is indicated based on the Ottawa ankle rules as mentioned above.

Treatment - Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE), which is recommended for 1–3 weeks. Protection in the form of crutches, splints, or brace may be added. Persistent problems at 12 weeks after injury, despite physiotherapy, may signal the need for operative treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following may be treated/may be achieved with the management modality demonstrated in the image below?

1 - Osteomyelitis
2 - Arthrodesis
3 - Nerve injury
4 - Limb lengthening
5 - Osteoporosis
questions.solution:
The management modality shown in the image is Ilizarov's technique. It is used in the following scenarios:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

Ilizarov's technique:

Distraction osteogenesis is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. Ilizarov described this as “the tension stress effect.”

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. 

Osteogenesis requires a dynamic state by either a controlled distraction or a controlled compression. This dynamic force causes dormant mesenchymal cells at the non-union site to differentiate into functioning osteoblasts. This results in bone synthesis and fracture healing. The fixation system is called a ring fixator.  Distraction or compression can be applied by twisting nuts on the fixation system at the fracture or corticotomy site.  Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings— ¼ mm, four times a day. This is used in limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic woman notices that on the extension of her fingers, the middle finger requires extra force to extend and snaps while doing so. There is an audible click when the finger is flexed. The extension is as depicted below. This is caused due to the involvement of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the video is a trigger finger which involves the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed. Early cases may be treated with a steroid injection into the tendon sheath.

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A cervical radiograph of a patient involved in a road traffic accident is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hangman's fracture.

The given cervical radiograph shows fracture of the pedicles of the C2 vertebra with an anterior translation of C2 over the C3 vertebra thus giving the diagnosis of hangman's fracture.

The mechanism of a traumatic hangman's fracture is hyperextension due to force to the forehead along with axial loading. It was incorrectly referred to previously as hangman's fracture due to the distractive force and death from spinal cord injury in judicial hanging. This results in anterior translation of the C2 vertebra over the C3 vertebra associated with pars interarticularis fracture of C2 which may extend up to the posterior body wall. Neurologic injury is unusual. 

Treatment:

Undisplaced fractures can be treated using semi-rigid arthrosis until united. Reduction with in-line traction followed by a semi-rigid collar in fractures with dislocation more than 3.5mm without kyphotic angulation. In cases of C2/C3 facet dislocation, open reduction and stabilization are required.

questions.text: A patient is managed with an implant for a tibial fracture 2 years back. He is now diagnosed with chronic osteomyelitis.  Which is the commonest organism to cause chronic osteomyelitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common causative agent of chronic osteomyelitis in the presence of surgical implants is staphylococcus epidermidis.

The most common organism involved in acute hematogenous osteomyelitis is staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever, Pain, and swelling are seen in acute exacerbation of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • In long-standing cases, the tissue gets thickened and folded inwards where a scar or a sinus get adheres to the underlying bone.
  • Presence of seropurulent discharge and skin excoriation surrounding it.

Radiological features include:

  • Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.
  • Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum. 
  • Cloacae are openings in the involucrum that allow drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured and her T-score is found to be -1.8. What does her T-score signify?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -1.8 signifies osteopenia. (T-score in osteopenia: -1 to -2.5).

Osteopenia refers to low bone mass with a T score of -1 to -2.5.

T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

Osteoporosis is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. 

A T-score of -1 or higher is considered normal.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. The X-ray image is given below. CT scan of the chest reveals metastasis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the sunburst appearance of the tumor at the metaphyseal end of a long bone, which is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

Other options:

Option A - Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Option D - Secondary metastasis from the prostate is typically densely osteosclerotic, in contrast to osteolytic renal and thyroid lesions. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Local and distal staging includes X-rays and MRI of the whole affected bone, bone scintigraphy, and CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. The most sensitive imaging modality for identifying metastases is the whole-body MRI.

questions.text:
A male patient presented with a bone fracture following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation and appeared confused and restless. Which of the following is not a part of the management of his current condition?

ESR- Erythrocyte sedimentation rate.
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of fat embolism and intercostal drainage is not a part of the management of this condition.

Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors: the release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats and actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Clinical features:

  • Early signs are fever and tachycardia
  • Presenting features are of 2 types
    • Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation
    • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia
  • Other features: petechial rash in front of neck/anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva

The classical clinical triad consists of respiratory distress, neurological abnormalities, and petechial haemorrhages

Treatment of fat embolism is mainly supportive:

  • Respiratory support (oxygen)
  • Heparinization (increases lipoprotein lipase activity)
  • Intravenous low molecular weight dextran
  • Corticosteroids: To avoid pneumonitis
  • Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: An infant with a large head and normal length was brought with failure to thrive. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and frontal bossing were noted. Blood tests show pancytopenia and X-ray imaging is done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A presentation of failure to thrive in an infant with a large head, normal length, pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and the X-ray image showing dense bones is suggestive of osteopetrosis. 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease:

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinical features: Macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigation: Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Radiological features: Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true with respect to this condition?

choices.text: Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in the extension-type
Almost all injuries are of the flexion-type
Cubitus valgus is the most common angular deformity

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus where vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. Gartland classification is used for the classification of supracondylar fractures and is of four types.

On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a fall on his hand during a football match. He complains of pain and inability to move his right shoulder. On examination, flattening of the shoulder contour and inability to touch his opposite shoulder are noted. He was managed using the method shown below. Identify the procedure shown.
questions.solution:
The history of a fall on his hand, loss of shoulder contour, and a positive Dugas test (inability to touch the opposite shoulder) are all suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation and the image shows Kocher's technique of reduction.

Kocher's technique- It is the most commonly used method for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four steps: 

Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation (TEAM)

  • Steady traction is applied along the long axis of the humerus with the elbow flexed to a right angle
  • Then the arm is externally rotated
  • This is followed by the adduction of the externally rotated arm
  • Finally, internal rotation is done.

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

It is the most common type of shoulder dislocation which results due to a fall on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. The patient usually presents with an abducted shoulder, with his elbow being supported by the opposite hand, and complains of pain and inability to move the affected shoulder.

The following findings are seen on examination:

  • Flattening of the normal shoulder contour.
  • A displaced head can be felt as a fullness below the clavicle.
  • Dugas test: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder
  • Hamilton ruler test: A ruler placed on the lateral side of the arm touches the acromion and lateral condyle of the humerus simultaneously due to the flattening of the shoulder.
  • Regiment badge sign: Area of anesthesia around the deltoid due to injury to the axillary nerve
  • Byrant's test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level.

Complications include injury to the axillary nerve and recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Other options:

Allis technique/maneuver is used for the reduction of posterior hip dislocation.

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to OPD with history of multiple bone fractures. Examination showed blue sclera, deformed legs and deformed teeth. What is the pathophysiology behind this condition?

choices.text: Defect in collagenous matrix of bone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. It occurs due to defect in the collagenous matrix of the bone.

Mutations in COL1A1 / COL1A2 results in defective collagen l synthesis. There are 12 types of osteogenesis imperfecta with type 1 being the most common. Triad of fragile bones, blue sclera and deafness is known as Van der Hoeve's syndrome. Treatment includes bisphosphonate therapy and orthopedic rehabilitation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of on-and-off back pain and stiffness in the morning that improves with exercise. Lately, she has been having persistent back pain and restricted chest movements. A CT scan was performed and is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Earliest X-ray finding is bamboo spine appearance
There is a strong association with HLA B27
Young males are more commonly affected

questions.solution:
The clinical description and CT image showing bony ankylosis of the spine continuously involving the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. Continuous ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament is present. The earliest/cardinal sign is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition of the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. It commonly involves young male adults.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

questions.text: A young man falls on an outstretched hand and develops a fracture as shown in the X-ray below.  Which of the following screws is commonly used to treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray and the history of falls on the outstretched hands suggest the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture. Herbert screw is commonly used to treat this fracture.

Herbert screw is a cannulated variable pitch screw, which is used to fix unstable or displaced fractures of small articular bones such as the scaphoid. This screw helps in quick healing by providing compression at the fracture site and early return to normal activities. The advantage of cannulated screws is that we can use a guidewire under videofluoroscopy to assist in the accurate placement of the screw during surgery.

Scaphoid fractures occur most commonly after a fall on an outstretched hand. The waist of the scaphoid is the most common site of fracture. Initial x-rays are done in anteroposterior, lateral, and oblique views. Even if the x-rays appear normal, if there is clinical suspicion, a glass holding cast should be applied for 2 weeks followed by repeat imaging.

Management depends upon the type of fracture. If the scaphoid tubercle is fractured, the patient is given a glass-holding cast for 4-6 weeks. In case of undisplaced waist fractures, most people will recover with a cast in place for 6-8 weeks. Percutaneous screw fixation with the Herbert screw can be offered to those with displaced or undisplaced fractures of the waist when the patient does not want to undergo prolonged cast immobilization, or if they wish to return to work/daily activities sooner. Reducing and fixing displaced fractures also reduces the risk of non-union.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Herbert screw is shown below:

 

Other options:

Option A: Cannulated cancellous screws are commonly used to treat fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B: The interference screw is a biodegradable screw used during anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction. This screw is made of polymers that increase its strength so as to improve cortical bone formation at the site as well as to ensure that the tibial tunnel is not too wide during the insertion of the newly reconstructed ligament.

Option D: Pedicle screws are used in spinal fusion surgery to provide added strength and support. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws, which prevent their movement and allow the bone to heal. They are also used in the correction of scoliosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida presents with pain and numbness in the first three digits of her hand. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and to relieve the pain she shakes her hand. She has a positive Phalen's and Tinel's test. Which among the following treatments will you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome(CTS). Carpal tunnel syndrome in pregnant females is first managed with wrist splinting.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) refers to the complex of symptoms and signs brought on by compression of the median nerve as it travels through the carpal tunnel. 

Clinical features:

  • Pain, paresthesia of the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. The symptoms are worse at night relieved by shaking or wringing their hands or by placing them under warm running water. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand.
  • Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan's test, direct median nerve compression is done. The presence of paresthesias and pain denotes median nerve compression.
  • Phalen's test - Elicited by holding the wrist flexed fully. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test. 
  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Clinical grading of CTS -

  • Mild -  Numbness, tingling, or discomfort in the median nerve distribution but no sensory loss, weakness, sleep disruption, or interference with activities of daily living (ADLs)
  • Moderate - Sensory loss in the median distribution, or if nocturnal symptoms occasionally disrupt sleep. However, ADLs are normal
  • Severe - If nocturnal symptoms routinely disrupt sleep, weakness in the median distribution, or the patient is unable to carry out ADLs.

Treatment: 

In cases of mild clinical symptoms splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Additionally in cases where it is pregnancy-induced wrist splinting may provide respite without the need for surgical interventions as the cause is transient and symptoms improve upon delivery. Surgical decompression is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male child from a remote area is being examined for a defect in his legs. The parents of the child give a history his legs were plastered for a few months after birth. However, there was a lapse in further follow-up. On examination, the child is suffering from uncorrected Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Which of the following is the best treatment option for the child?
questions.solution:
As the child is having Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) and his age is 12, Triple arthrodesis is the best treatment option for this child.

Triple arthrodesis consists of a fusion of the three joints of the foot-Talo-navicular joint, Talo-calcaneal joint, and Calcaneo-cuboid joint. It is done after 10-12 years of age when there is complete skeletal maturation. Of the three talonavicular joint fusion is the most difficult to achieve.

CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot. It is predominately seen in male children. The components of deformity are as follows:

  • Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  • Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint. The calcaneum is inverted and along with it, the whole foot is inverted. This leads to a medially facing sole. 
  • Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to the OPD by her mother as she noticed some deformity in the hip and lower limbs of the child. On examination,  asymmetry of groin crease is seen and the following test in the image is positive. What is the name of the test being performed?
questions.solution:
Galeazzi's test is shown in the above image.

It is done in children with unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) between 3 to 8 months of age.

The child is placed supine with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both the knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen to be at a lower level indicating femoral shortening. This is also known as Alli's sign.

Tests for DDH are:

  • Barlow's test
  • Ortolani's test
  • Galeazzi's test
  • Asymmetric skin fold test

Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In this test, direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.

questions.text: An elder sibling is playing with his 3-year-old sister and he pulls up the child by holding hands. The child starts crying, does not use her arm, and does not let anybody touch it. She presents to the orthopaedics unit with the limb in the position as shown in the image. No swelling or focal point tenderness is elicited but she cries when supination is attempted. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The history of lifting the child by the forearm and later the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow. The subluxation of the radial head is the possible cause in this case.

Pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow is the radial head subluxation from the annular ligament seen more commonly in children less than 6 years of age. 

The underlying mechanism in this deformity is the subluxation of the radial head under the annular ligament and not the olecranon process (option B). This is due to the longitudinal traction applied on an extended and supinated forearm. The clinical features include severe pain and the inability to use the affected arm. Characteristically the child holds the elbow in extension or slight flexion with the forearm pronated as shown in the image above.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of the mechanism of development of a pulled elbow:

 

The diagnosis is usually clinical but a radiograph is obtained to exclude a fracture.

It can be treated by the closed reduction technique of forearm flexion with supination. Immobilization using a sling can be used for symptomatic relief.

Other options:

Option B: Subluxation of the olecranon process is seen in posterior dislocation of the elbow. It often occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand. Examination of the elbow joint may show swelling, deformity, or bruising. Posterior elbow dislocations often present with an upper extremity that is flexed and appears shortened. Initial workup involves X-ray in anteroposterior and lateral view. CT scan is considered when the injury is complex. Simple cases are usually treated with closed reductions.

Option C- Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most common fracture in children. It results from a fall on an outstretched hand. The fracture lies just above the condyles of the humerus with angulation or displacement of the distal fragment. The clinical features include pain and a swollen elbow. Option D- Avulsion of the olecranon process results from the eccentric contraction of the triceps tendon.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life.

The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless. Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity. 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the given image is Adson's test done for thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus(C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels between the clavicle and the first rib. This produces neurological vascular symptoms. The compression can be due to an extra rib or due to abnormal scalene muscles, etc.

Clinical features:

Even though the anomalies responsible for this condition are congenital, symptoms appear during the third decade. This is because the blood vessels that supply the trunk level of the brachial plexus become less compliant in the third decade. 

The patient presents with pain and paresthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm and the medial two fingers. Ulnar clawing and wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the hand may be seen. Vascular signs are less common but the presence of unilateral Raynauds phenomenon should raise suspicion of thoracic outlet syndrome. 

Tests for thoracic outlet syndrome are provocative maneuvers that are performed to reproduce the signs and symptoms of this condition.

These provocative tests are not sensitive nor specific to making a diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Treatment:

Conservative management consists of shoulder muscle strengthening, postural training, and analgesics for pain.

Surgical management is indicated if there is severe pain, obvious muscle wasting, or presence of vascular disturbances. The cervical rib is removed via a supraclavicular or trans-axillary approach. 

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a painful, slow and gradual enlargement at the insertion of the Achilles tendon. It gets relieved with rest.  On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and patient image point towards the diagnosis of Haglund deformity. 

Haglund deformity refers to a large exostosis at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneal tuberosity located anterior to the Achilles tendon. 

This pre-tendinous bursitis usually is caused by chronic irritation from a shoe heel counter. Modification of shoe wear usually relieves symptoms. 

Treatment includes mainly conservative management. Surgical treatment is indicated if conservative management fails.

 

Option A) Hallux valgus (shown below) is caused due to the excessive lateral deviation of the great toe with the prominence of the head of the first metatarsal. It can be congenital or a consequence of rheumatoid arthritis or excessive usage of footwear with narrow toe space. The commonest complaints are pain over the bunion, worries about cosmesis and difficulty fitting shoes. Often there is also deformity of the lesser toes and pain in the forefoot. 

 

Option B: In plantar fasciitis, there is pain and tenderness in the sole of the foot, mostly under the heel, with standing or walking. The condition progresses gradually, without any clear incident or injury, but sometimes there is a history of sudden increase in sporting activity, or a change of footwear, sports shoes or running surface. There may be an associated tightness of the Achilles tendon. 

Option D: Tarsal coalition usually occurs in older children and teenagers where they present with a painful, rigid flat foot in which the peroneal and extensor tendons are in spasm.

questions.text: You are asked to measure the degree of lateral curvature present in a patient with scoliosis using the method depicted below. Identify this method.
questions.solution:
In the given X-ray of a patient with scoliosis, the degree of lateral curvature is measured using Cobb's method. The degree of curvature of scoliosis on plain radiographs is measured using Cobb's angle.

To measure the Cobbs's angle, first locate the superior-end vertebra and inferior-end vertebra of the curve. Then draw perpendicular lines to the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and to the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra.

The angle formed at the intersection of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle. It can also be measured by measuring the angle made by the intersection of the end-plate lines. 

Note: Nash and Moe's method, Perdriolle and Vidal method, and Stokes method are methods of assessing vertebral rotation.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents to the OPD for evaluation of low backache. He also feels pain in the back of the leg and at the ankles. MRI reveals protrusion of the disc at the L4-L5 level. Which of the following would be an absolute indication for surgical management in this patient?

choices.text: if patient with sciatica does not improve with epidural steroid injection
if patient is diagnosed with cauda equina syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and MRI findings point towards the diagnosis of intervertebral disc prolapse and associated sciatica pain. Cauda equina syndrome is the only absolute and urgent indication for surgery in such cases.

The relative indications for elective surgery in disc prolapse include:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Progressive neurological deficit
  • Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica
  • Pain not relieved by complete rest from activities

The aim of the surgery is to relieve the pressure on the nerve root. The prolapsed disc is removed (discectomy), followed by stabilization of the spine.  

In most cases of disc prolapse, improvement occurs with conservative management over 6 weeks. 

Conservative therapy for this condition includes:

  • Bed rest
  • Heat
  • Ice
  • Analgesics
  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Antidepressants
  • Muscle relaxants
  • Massage
  • Acupuncture
  • epidural steroid injection
  • Spinal traction
  • Optimum physical activity

questions.text: What is the most common complication of pelvic fractures?
questions.solution:
Acute haemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is the most common complication of pelvic fractures. 

In fractures of the pelvic ring, there is a risk of injury to the major vessels (internal iliac and external iliac vessels) and to the venous plexus around the sacroiliac joint. Bleeding from the venous plexus is the major cause of pelvic haemorrhage.

Potential blood loss in fractures is given below:

Fracture site Potential blood loss
Pelvis  > 2 litres 
Femur 1 - 2 litres
Tibia or fibula 0.5 - 1.5 litres

Pelvic fractures have a high mortality rate ranging from 10% to 50% in some open pelvic fractures. Early mortality is mostly the result of haemorrhage. Late mortality occurs from sepsis or multiple system organ failure.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. He was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency rickets. Which of the following is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The level of serum alkaline phosphatase is increased in this child with vitamin D deficiency rickets.

Nutritional rickets occur due to a deficiency of vitamin D. This leads to low calcium levels in the blood. To raise the serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises. The parathyroid hormone tries to raise the calcium levels by :

  • Reabsorbing calcium in the kidneys and secreting phosphate in exchange leads to low phosphate levels
  • Increasing bone resorption

Lab findings:

  • Serum calcium- decreased
  • Serum phosphorus- decreased
  • Creatinine- normal
  • Alkaline phosphatase- increased
  • Urinary excretion of calcium- decreased

Radiological features of rickets:
