questions.text: A 55-year-old female complains of pain in her knee. She notices pain when rising up from a sitting position and climbing up stairs. She states she has morning stiffness for around 10 minutes every morning in her knees. X-ray findings are normal. Which of the following is the first line for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Exercise to strengthen muscles around knee

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a middle-aged female complaining of knee pain with activity associated with brief morning stiffness is suggestive of osteoarthritis (OA). For mild disease, non-pharmacologic management with exercises must be tried first. 

Osteoarthritis:

Clinical presentation:

Pain is the most frequent symptom of OA. It is worse with joint use and relieved by rest. It progresses through three stages -

  • Stage 1 – Predictable, sharp pain usually brought on by a mechanical insult that eventually limits high-impact activities with a relatively modest effect on function.
  • Stage 2 – Pain becomes more constant and starts to affect daily activities. There may be unpredictable episodes of stiffness.
  • Stage 3 – Constant dull/aching pain punctuated by episodes of often unpredictable, intense, exhausting pain that results in severe limitations in function.

Other findings include tenderness, limitation of movement, bony swelling, and instability.

Diagnosis: It is generally a clinical diagnosis. Peripheral joint OA may be diagnosed confidently on clinical grounds alone if the following are present:

  1. Persistent usage-related joint pain in one or few joints
  2. Age ≥45 years
  3. Morning stiffness ≤30 minute

X-ray imaging may be used to strengthen a diagnosis of osteoarthritis. An X-ray may show joint space narrowing or may even be normal

Treatment:

  • Nonpharmacological Therapy - Exercises to strengthen muscles around the knee, weight loss, and bracing for malalignment(Option B) may be tried initially.
  • Pharmacological Therapy - NSAIDS, topical capsaicin, and duloxetine may be used.
  • Surgery - Total joint replacement may be indicated in severe disease after failure of other treatment modalities(Option D).

Other options:

Option C: Allopurinol is used for the management of gout.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man twists his right knee while playing in a football game a few days back. He immediately felt the knee swell. At presentation, he reports that the knee catches and locks intermittently. On examination, there is tenderness along the affected joint line. An MRI revealed a meniscal tear and he underwent meniscal tear repair. Which of the following zones of the meniscus is likely to heal last?
questions.solution:
The white zone heals last in case of a meniscal tear due to its poor blood supply. On the other hand, the red zone heals best due to its rich blood supply.

The menisci are supplied by perimeniscal blood vessels from superior and inferior branches of medial and lateral genicular vessels. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular. By adulthood, only the peripheral 10% to 25% of the tissue is perfused. This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci:

  • The peripheral relatively vascularised region is called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
  • A zone of transition between the 2 zones, is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
  • The completely avascular inner zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)

There is a direct relationship between vascularization and the capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent post-traumatic and degenerative lesions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old obese woman who recently joined a weight loss program presents with pain along the anterior and medial aspects of her tibia. The pain increases while doing jogging and walking on the treadmill for long periods. On examination, there is diffuse tenderness along the tibial shaft. A plain X-ray radiograph of her leg is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with diffuse tibial pain and a normal x-ray is the shin splint or medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS). 

MTSS is a stress injury of the tibia which occurs due to the frequent overuse of lower limbs. It is commonly seen in athletes and military personnel.

Risk factors for MTSS

  • High body mass index (BMI)
  • An increase in training volume or intensity
  • Female gender
  • Previous history of MTSS

Exercise-induced diffuse pain along the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border is typical. Since it is a stress injury, the radiograph of the leg appears normal.

MTSS often leads to stress fractures of the tibia. When this occurs, the pain increases in intensity becomes localized and is associated with swelling.

It is treated conservatively. The patient should take physical rest and modify daily activities to avoid repetitive and load-bearing exercises. Other modalities being studied include ice massage and ultrasound therapy.

questions.text: The radiological investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is ________
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is MRI as initially, bone infarction occurs in the marrow.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition resulting from diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of actions is also a feature of this condition.

The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. MRI has high sensitivity and specificity in diagnosis.

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis and total or partial replacement are preferred.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.
